title: Understanding Spontaneity
text: For a reaction to be spontaneous, the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) must be negative. How can you relate ΔG to enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS)?

title: Gibbs Free Energy Equation
text: Recall the formula for Gibbs free energy change: ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS. Use this equation and set ΔG to be less than zero for spontaneity.

title: Substitute the Known Values
text: Substitute the given values for ΔH $$(-92.6$$ kJ/mol) and ΔS $$(-198.3$$ J/mol·K). Remember to convert units where necessary.

title: Convert Units
text: Convert the entropy change ΔS from $$\frac{J}{mol·K}$$ to $$\frac{kJ}{mol·K}$$. Divide by $$1000$$ to get $$-0.1983$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol·K}$$.

title: Reformulate the Equation
text: Using the given values, rewrite the equation as: ΔG $$=$$ $$-92.6$$ - $$T(-0.1983)$$.

title: Solve for Temperature
text: Set up the inequality for spontaneity: $$-92.6$$ - $$T(-0.1983)$$ < $$0$$. Solve for T.

title: Calculate the Critical Temperature
text: Rearrange the inequality to T > $$\frac{-92.6}{\left(-0.1983\right)}$$. Calculate T to find the critical temperature for which the reaction becomes spontaneous.

title: Final Calculation Check
text: Perform the calculation for T to verify the temperature limit for spontaneity.
